pointsOfInterest.shortDescription: Immediately after the toll, the road switches from flat to steep. Looking left, you see the last of the 'Duars' plains before the hills swallow the horizon.
The road carves through manicured tea bushes. On the Right, look for the 'Rohini Rock Viewpoint,' a popular spot where massive boulders sit amidst the tea.
Dudhia | Balason River with Dudhia Bridge
As you approach Kurseong via the 'Snake Road,' the Giddapahar Viewpoint appears. This is a famous photographer's spot. You can see the road you just climbed looping below you like a ribbon.
Located at the highest point of Kurseong. You get a 360-degree view. To the South, the plains of Siliguri; to the North, the first peek of the high Himalayas.
View from the scenic village of Munsong (or Mansong/Mungsong) in the Kalimpong district of West Bengal.
The Samdrup Darjay Choling Monastery appears with its bright colors.
The stretch between Sonada and Ghoom is lined with Dhupi (Himalayan Pine) trees. The sun rarely hits the road here; it’s a tunnel of green and grey mist.
Look for the dense, dark forests on your right. This is where the rare Himalayan Salamander lives in small, hidden lakes.
The final 'reveal.' The mountain opens up. You see the War Memorial, the spiral tracks, and—if luck is on your side—the entire panorama.
